content: The "Pet and Women Safety Act of 2017" may be cited as the official title. It addresses pet involvement in crimes related to domestic violence and stalking. The "Pet and Women Safety Act of 2017" addresses pet involvement in crimes related to domestic violence and stalking by amending sections 2261A and 2262 of title 18, United States Code. It includes provisions for protecting pets of individuals involved in stalking and domestic violence situations. The "Pet and Women Safety Act of 2017" amends various sections of title 18, United States Code to include protection for pets in cases of domestic violence and stalking. This includes adding provisions for veterinary services for the victim's pet and defining "pet" in the context of the law. The "Pet and Women Safety Act of 2017" amends title 18, United States Code to protect pets in cases of domestic violence and stalking. It includes provisions for veterinary services for the victim's pet and defines a pet as a domesticated animal kept for pleasure. The "Emergency and Transitional Pet Shelter and Housing Assistance Grant Program" is established under SEC. 3 to provide aid for pets in cases of domestic violence and stalking. The Secretary of Agriculture will award grants to eligible entities to provide assistance to victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking and their pets. Eligible entities must submit an application describing the activities for which the grant is sought. Eligible entities seeking grants must provide assurances for compliance, disclose mandatory reporting duties to victims, and avoid proposing activities that compromise victim safety. The eligible entities seeking grants must provide assurances for compliance, disclose mandatory reporting duties to victims, and avoid proposing activities that compromise victim safety. The proposals should include background checks and clinical evaluations for victims, without requiring mandatory services or protective orders. The entity's understanding of domestic violence dynamics should be reflected, and victims should not be forced to participate in the criminal justice system to receive services. Grants awarded under this section may only be used for programs that provide emergency and transitional shelter and housing assistance for domestic violence victims with pets, including short-term shelter and housing assistance. Grants under this section can be used for temporary shelter, housing, and support services for domestic violence victims with pets, including pet-related services and training for stakeholders. The eligible entity receiving a grant must agree to confidentiality requirements and provide training on the link between domestic violence and pet abuse, the needs of victims, support services, referrals, and confidentiality. The entity receiving a grant must provide assistance to domestic violence victims for up to 24 months, with a possible 6-month extension. Assistance should not be conditioned on victims participating in support services. The entity receiving a grant must provide assistance to domestic violence victims for up to 24 months, with a possible 6-month extension. Victims who have tried but failed to find permanent housing for their pets can receive assistance. Reports to the Secretary and Congress are required annually, detailing the assistance provided to domestic violence victims with pets. The Secretary must report to Congress biennially on the assistance provided to domestic violence victims with pets, compiling information from previous reports. The report is also shared with relevant departments like the Department of Justice and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Authorization of Appropriations: $3,000,000 authorized annually from 2017 to 2021 for the Administration for Children and Families. Limitation: Not more than 5% for evaluation, monitoring, salaries, and administrative expenses. Definitions include "domestic violence victim" and "eligible entity" such as States and local governments. The curr_chunk discusses eligible entities for funding related to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking, including various organizations with a history of effective work in these areas. The curr_chunk defines "pet" as a domesticated animal kept for pleasure, and references terms from the Violence Against Women Act of 1994. Congress believes that States should include protections for pets in domestic violence protection orders.
